item.title: WEEK 12: Screen Layout
item.description: Study materials: Study material: DOWNLOAD Homework assignment: No homework assignment. Lecture summary: The lecture covers important features of computer-based learning, focusing on providing clear information to learners about the material’s purpose, structure, and support. Effective assessment involves pre-tests and post-tests, self-assessment, and reflective activities to gauge learner progress. The content should be engaging, learner-centered, and presented in manageable chunks. Various media, such as text, graphics, color, sound, video, and animation, should be used appropriately to enhance the learning environment.

item.title: WEEK 5: Text
item.description: Study materials: Study material: DOWNLOAD Homework assignment: No assignment. Lecture summary: Text remains a potent medium for conveying information in computer-based learning, despite the rise of multimedia. On-screen text presentation shares similarities with print but differs notably in quality due to lower resolution, although this has improved over the past decade. Screens typically offer less space and landscape orientation, contrasting with the portrait layout of pages. Reading extensive text on screens is generally harder and slower than from books, attributed to poorer resolution and potential color variations for text and background.

item.description: Study materials: Study material: DOWNLOAD Homework assignment: You can access and submit your assignment at the following LINK. Each assignment has a deadline. Once the deadline has passed, the system will no longer accept any additional submissions. IMPORTANT: You can login to the assignment only with your IBU-issued email address. Lecture summary: The lecture introduced Computer Aided Education by defining key terms: computer, aided, and education. It posed critical questions regarding the role of computers in enhancing learning, the adoption by schools, the impact on student interest, benefits for children, the potential to replace teachers, and the future importance of digital literacy over traditional literacy.
